lineage.Process: CalculateGeometryAttributes Kenya_adm1_uscb_2023 "area AREA_GEODESIC" # "Square Kilometers" GEOGCS["GCS_WGS_1984",DATUM["D_WGS_1984",SPHEROID["WGS_1984",6378137.0,298.257223563]],PRIMEM["Greenwich",0.0],UNIT["Degree",0.0174532925199433]] "Same as input"

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Length of feature in internal units.

attrdomv.udom: Positive real numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Area of feature in internal units squared.

attrdomv.udom: Positive real numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Name of the country or subnational area (administrative division).

Concatenation of all administrative division names separated by underscores ("_"), beginning with the country name and ending with the division name for the lowest subnational administrative order (level). The field serves as one for name sorting and ordering.

Identical subnational area identifiers in the Excel table, geospatial data file, and Unicode text table, enabling linkage (joining) of the table records to the geospatial data file polygons as attributes.
First-order administrative division name (ADM1), i.e., counties.
Administrative level "0" (ADM0/country); administrative level "1" (ADM1); administrative level "2" (ADM2); administrative level "3" (ADM3); administrative level "4" (ADM4).
Any notes about Kenya or its subnational divisions, which may include former names or alternate names or spellings.
U.S. Government Geopolitical Entities, Names, and Codes (GENC) Standard (for country and first-order administrative divisions only).
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Government Geopolitical Entities, Names, and Codes (GENC), 2023

attr.attrdef: U.S. Government Federal Information Processing System (FIPS) code (for country and first-order administrative divisions only).
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Government Federal Information Processing System (FIPS), 2023

attr.attrdef: Code used by the Kenya National Bureau of Statistics for a subnational administrative division.

dataIdInfo.idAbs: Annual five-year age group population estimates by sex for 2015 to 2030 for the national and first-order administrative division levels of Kenya were prepared by the U.S. Census Bureau for joining (linking) to shapefiles as attribute data. The estimates are consistent with the midyear national projections from the U.S. Census Bureau International Database (IDB).
dataIdInfo.idPurp: The U.S. Census Bureau is providing annual subnational five-year age group population estimates by sex for Kenya for 2015-2030 in a geographic information system (GIS) for users of the Spatial Data Repository, funded by the U.S. President’s Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR).
dataIdInfo.idCredit:
CENSUS DATA 2019 Age-Sex Data: 2019 Kenya Population and Housing Census, Volume III: Distribution of Population by Age and Sex, Table 2.3: Distribution of Population by Age, Sex, County and Sub-County. Kenya National Bureau of Statistics. Available online at http://www.knbs.or.ke/?wpdmpro=2019-kenya-population-and-housing-census-volume-iii-distribution-of-population-by-age-sex-and-administrative-units (accessed September 19, 2023).
2009 Population Total Data: 2009 Kenya Population and Housing Census, Volume IA: Population Distribution by Administrative Units, Table 2: Population Distribution by Sex, Number of Households, Area, Density, and Administrative Units. Kenya National Bureau of Statistics. Available online at http://www.knbs.or.ke/download/volume-1a-population-distribution-by-administrative-units/ (accessed September 19, 2023).
The U.S. Census Bureau cannot guarantee the accuracy of non-U.S. census and survey data.
GEOSPATIAL BOUNDARIES International boundaries coincide with the Large Scale International Boundaries (LSIB) dataset from the U.S. Department of State, Office of the Geographer and Global Issues. Available online at http://geonode.state.gov (accessed September 19, 2023).
Geospatial data for the first-order administrative divisions of Kenya were downloaded from DevInfo at http://devinfo.org/di_digital_map_library.html, "afr_ken_l04_2003" and "afr_ken_l05_2003" (no longer available online). These fourth and fifth-order administrative boundaries from 2003 were recombined by USCB staff to create the second-order administrative boundaries reflective of the subnational administrative structure used in Kenya's 2019 census.
The U.S. Census Bureau cannot guarantee the accuracy of boundary placements.
NATIONAL ESTIMATES AND PROJECTIONS U.S. Census Bureau, Population Division. International Database, August 2023 release, available online at http://www.census.gov/data-tools/demo/idb/ (accessed September 19, 2023).
NATIONAL AND SUBNATIONAL AREA NAMES AND CODES (1) U.S. National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency. NGA Geographic Names Server (GNS), available at http://geonames.nga.mil/geonames/GNSHome/welcome.html (accessed September 19, 2023). Contains geographic area names from the U.S. Board on Geographic Names and the U.S. Government Federal Information Processing System (FIPS) codes. (2) U.S. Government Geopolitical Entities, Names, and Codes (GENC) Standard. NSG Standards Registry, available at http://nsgreg.nga.mil/genc/discovery (accessed September 19, 2023).

Consts.useLimit: U.S. Census Bureau population estimates: None. Acknowledgment of the Census Bureau would be appreciated in products derived from its population estimates. The subnational boundaries used for this shapefile were downloaded by the U.S. Census Bureau from a publicly available source for this product. The international boundaries are derived from the Large Scale International Boundaries (LSIB) dataset (public domain).

dataIdInfo.suppInfo:
SUBNATIONAL DIVISIONS Kenya's first-order administrative divisions: 47 counties as of the 2019 census.
SHAPEFILES The original shapefile downloaded from the had 2,433 polygons and matched the 2019 census sub-counties (second-order administrative divisions), after several changes to the subnational boundaries by USCB staff: (1) Location (fourth-order) polygons from the DevInfo afr_ken_l04_2003 shapefile, along with some sub-location (fifth-order) polygons from the DevInfo afr_ken_l05 _2003 shapefile, were combined by USCB staff to create 345 sub-county polygons that matched the 2019 census administrative configuration, as noted in the USCBCMNT field. Most 2019 sub-county polygons were formed by merging groups of whole location polygons, but in some cases, location polygons had to be split along sub-location boundaries to form the new sub-counties. (2) As mentioned below, ten forest and national park sub-counties contained very small populations that were combined with neighboring sub-counties for the purposes of this product. Likewise, polygons for the ten forest and national park sub-counties were merged with the polygons of neighboring sub-counties by USCB staff, decreasing the number of polygons to 335. (3) Shorelines for the Indian Ocean, Lake Victoria, and Lake Turkana were digitized by USCB staff. Polygons were created representing the portions of the two lakes that fall within the international boundary of Kenya, bringing the number of polygons to 337. (4) The original shapefile was misaligned with features on the ground and contained many topological errors such as gaps, slivers, and overlapping polygons. USCB staff realigned the shapefile to Esri basemap imagery using the rubbersheet spatial adjustment tool in ArcMap, and topological errors were corrected using several geoprocessing techniques.
These changes resulted in a shapefile with 337 polygons, one for each of Kenya's second-order administrative divisions, one for Lake Victoria, and one for Lake Turkana. The U.S. Census Bureau aligned the shapefile's national boundary to the Large Scale International Boundary Line (LSIB) dataset from the U.S. Department of State, Office of the Geographer and Global Issues. Finally, the LSIB-aligned shapefile was dissolved into 49 polygons, one for each of Kenya's first-order administrative divisions (counties) as reported by the Kenya National Bureau of Statistics in the 2019 census, one for Lake Victoria, and one for Lake Turkana.
CENSUS DATA INTERPOLATION The 2009 census totals had the following differences in geography that have been modified to their 2019 locations in the estimates presented here, requiring interpolation and adjustment of 2009 population data by USCB staff: (1) At the time of its 2009 census, Kenya's first-order administrative divisions consisted of 8 provinces, composed of 158 districts (second-order), approximately 500 divisions (third-order), approximately 2,400 locations (fourth-order), and approximately 6,600 sub-locations (fifth-order). The 2010 Constitution of Kenya reorganized the country into the 47 counties (first-order), composed of 345 sub-counties (second-order), used during the 2019 census. (2) District, division, location, and sub-location population totals from the 2009 census were recombined by USCB staff to fit the 345 sub-county administrative configuration in use during the 2019 census, as noted in the USCBCMNT field. In some cases, 2009 districts or divisions became 2019 sub-counties without boundary changes. However, most 2019 sub-counties were formed from multiple 2019 divisions, or parts of divisions that were split along location or sub-location boundaries.
New sub-counties were formed from parts of a single area or multiple areas, and boundaries and population data were available for the next administrative level down. The total population of the original area in 2009 was divided according to the populations of the lower-level areas.
ADDITIONAL NOTES (1) The 80-84 through 100-and-above age groups in the original 2019 census data were summed by USCB staff into the 80PL age group used in this product. (2) The 2019 Kenya census included an "unknown age" field, which was divided and redistributed among the age groups for each sex by USCB staff, according to each age group's percentage of the total population by sex. (3) The 2019 Kenya census included some forest and national park areas as administrative sub-counties. Ten of these areas contained very small populations that were combined with neighboring sub-counties by USCB staff, as noted in the USCBCMNT field. Populations of five Mount Kenya Forest sub-counties were combined with Buuri West, Maara, Embu East, Kieni East, and Kirinyaga East Sub-counties. Populations of two Aberdare Forest sub-counties were combined with Kieni West and Mathioya Sub-counties. The population of Aberdare National Park was combined with Nyandarua North Sub-county, the population of Mau Forest was combined with Narok North Sub-county, and the population of Kakamega Forest was combined with Hamisi Sub-county. (4) The Kenya Bureau of National Statistics acknowledged substantial undercounting in Garissa County during the 2019 census enumeration process, but revised data had yet to be published by the agency when this product was created. USCB staff substituted the undercounted census data with population estimates derived from the Garissa County Annual Development Plan, Financial Year 2020/2021, available online at http://garissa.go.ke/downloads/#1544007603949-cd0442d9-5b6f for download. (5) The Kenya Bureau of National Statistics reported anomalies in their 2009 census publications in the districts that would form Wajir, Mandera, and Turkana Counties, observing higher than expected population growth rates and significant deviations from expected age and sex patterns. The 2009 population totals for the sub-counties within these three counties were recalculated by USCB staff to reflect the nation-level growth rate observed between the 2009 and 2019 censuses.
FEATURE AND ATTRIBUTE DETAILS The 2015-2030 population estimates for Kenya's administrative divisions are provided in the following two tables: (1) The Unicode tab-delimited text file (table) "Kenya_5yr_age_sex_2015-2030_uscb_nov2023.txt," which can be joined to the shapefile via the common field "GEO_MATCH." (2) The Excel table "Kenya_5yr_age_sex_2015-2030_508_uscb_nov2023.xlsx," formatted for accessibility in compliance with Section 508 of the U.S. Government's Federal Rehabilitation Act.
Details on processing of the census data and calculation of 2015-2030 estimates are provided in the "Census Metadata" tab of the Excel file and "Methods for Calculating 5-Year Age Group Population Estimates by Sex for Subnational Areas" document. For the subnational areas, the U.S. Board on Geographic Names (BGN) "approved" names from the NGA Geographic Names Server (cited in the "Credits") were used. For any area that a BGN name was not available, the name from the national census was used. Official codes for the subnational areas from the country's national statistical office, when available, are entered in the "NSO_CODE" field in both the text and Excel tables. Information on any alternative area names or recent name or boundary changes is entered in the "USCBCMNT" field. A partial list of the fields in the Excel and Unicode text files, including all fields identifying geographic names and codes, is provided in the Excel file's "Data Dictionary" tab. More detail on the U.S. Census Bureau subnational age and sex group estimates and maps for PEPFAR can be found in the document "Subnational Population Estimates Components for the Spatial Data Repository." It includes a data dictionary that is similar to that in the Excel table.
METHODOLOGY For more information, see the following methodology documents in the Spatial Data Repository: (1) "U.S. Census Bureau Methodology for SDR Subnational Population Estimates." (2) "U.S. Census Bureau Methods for Calculating 5-Year Age Group Population Estimates by Sex for Subnational Areas." (3) "Instructions for Joining Subnational Population Data to Shapefiles."
ACCESS The U.S. Census Bureau’s products for PEPFAR can be accessed from the Spatial Data Repository at http://spatialdata.dhsprogram.com/home/, which also provides access to data and maps from the DHS (Demographic and Health Surveys) Program. A zipped file containing shapefiles with metadata, an Excel workbook with subnational population estimates, and a Unicode tab-delimited text file is available for each country. PEPFAR products are also available on the Census Bureau website at http://www.census.gov/geographies/mapping-files/time-series/demo/international-programs/subnationalpopulation.html for download.
